_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility has developed a risk management program to address Requirements for the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP).( 40 CFR Part 68 - "Risk Management Programs (RMP) for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention". (EPA)) The facility is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community.  The facilityA?s staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia for NOX Reduction.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Selective Catalytic Reduction System.  CalPine - Pastoria Energy FacilityA?s policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance. 

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The facility utilizes ammonia for their Selective Catalytic Reduction System to control nitrous oxide emissions.  264,000 pounds of ammonia are contained in the two Ammonia Storage Tanks if the tanks are kept at maximum capacity.      

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case analysis has been defined for the process.  The results can be found in the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab located in the RMP Compliance Workbook.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: A realistic alternative release scenario was defined for the process.  The results can be found in the HAZARD ASSESSMENT Tab located in the RMP Compliance Workbook.

Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks; CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility has rec

ognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and facility personnel to make this worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent. Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is shown in the model).
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:
A?    There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place.
A?    The system undergoes scheduled maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.
A?    Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by facility personnel, as necessary.
The history of CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility (i.e., no RMP -applicable ammonia releases in the last five years) reflects the adequacy of the design and diligence of the plant staff in safely operating the Selective Catalytic Reduction System. 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM
As part of the implementation of RMP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia. Prevention Program 3 elements are listed in the following table:

Compliance Workbook Tab
Process Safety Information (PSI) 
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
Operating Procedures (OP)
Training (TRN)
Mechanical Integrity (MI)
Management of Change (MOC)
Pre-Startup Review (PSSR)
Compliance Audits (CA)
Incident Investigation (II)
Employee Participation (EP

)
Hot Work Permit (HWP)
Contractors (CON)
Emergency Planning & Response (EP&R)

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 
There have been no RMP-applicable releases of ammonia at the facility in at least the past five years.  

FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE
The use of flammable materials at CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 

FLAMMABLES: ALTERNATIVE RELEASE 
The use of flammable materials at CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.

EMERGENCY PLANNING & RESPONSE 
CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility does not assume the role of first responder during an emergency. CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility has an Emergency Action Plan, which can be found in Attachment A of the EMERGENCY PLANNING & RESPONSE Tab and this plan includes:
A?    Emergency Alarm Procedures
A?    Evacuation Procedures
A?    Safety and Health Considerations
A?    Notification Procedures

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 
CalPine - Pastoria Energy Facility is extremely diligent in the handling of ammonia. Planned changes to improve safety and the CalARP/RMP/PSM Program are listed in the Action Item Tracking Log as recommendations in APPENDIX A.
